page.title: 07Barnby in the W. Farming 3
page.content: The majority of the land around Barnby is given over to arable farming. There is a relatively small amount of mixed woodland used mainly for game cover, none of it being used for commercial timber production. As in many other parts of the country the majority of the elm trees which grew in the area have been lost to Dutch Elm Disease. This, together with the present day farming fanaticism for uprooting hedgerows to give bigger and bigger fields, has had a considerable effect on the appearance and ecology of the area. The principal crops grown in the area are cereals, with sugar beet and oilseed rape being used as break crops. Each year there is a surplus of straw because of low local demand. This results in a certain amount of straw burning in the fields each year.
